title: Is it possible that books shape how we think? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, but that is a two-way (book and me), even a three-way (book, my community and me) street. Two-way: A lone individual unconsciously interprets the book based on who they are, yet who one is already has been shaped genetically and by ones community. Three-way: A book read in a group, or with knowledge/memory of an interpretive tradition, will greatly shape and constrain how one interprets the book—and how one thinks. PSA major issue I have with the Quora community is that many atheists in the western world are former believers, or were raised by former believers—believers in an extremely literal, conservative brand of religion. —So there is this constant internal debate between fundamentalists and ex-fundamentalists, that loses sight of 99% of the alternatives.

The answer is most definitely. Our education systems are built on knowledge stored in books. Ideas find books the last place of refuge from a mindless world. Indeed, as Steinfelt claimed, books are the last evidence that people still think.
